ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Appreciation for Middle English lyric, some middle english pronunciation skills, greater musical context about lyric, love of the Medieval & manuscripts
I became better at breaking down literature from the base of what it was
can read middle english quite decently now, which although not really useful, still kind of neat. and I got my medieval era requirement
Learned how to think about Medieval English poetry as lyric, especially considering how its layout on the page colors its interpretation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The content was very engaging and the selections were all great. Sometimes the class discussions felt like they didn't have enough direction, but sometimes as well the class would get into really exhilirating back-and-forth discussions. I think the course needs just a bit better time management within class discussions.

Good content and interesting topics

I think there were no true flaws

weaknesses:
on a whole, the seminars were quite boring, and only the glee people seemed enthusiastic, but only when it was about the musical parts of the text.  there are only ever about two medieval era courses offered a semester, which is a requirement for the English major to graduate. which many majors already don't think there should be a medieval requirement. or at least diversify and add more classes. there was nothing really in content that I haven't already gotten from english foundational courses. 

the essay prompts were not prompts. they were "suggestions" like "what does medieval lyric say about lyric? about song? about rhythm? about repetition? about women? about Mary?" just super amorphous and not very helpful. and then the feedback on the essay felt like she had expected a more pinpointed argument when she hadn't given us a pinpointed area of focus.

we'd spend all of class saying nothing about the songlines. just translating them and reading them aloud. not adding anything of note to them or our understanding of them. it felt very pointless and two other students I talked to also had no idea what we were supposed to be doing or why it mattered. 

strengths:
despite all this, it was not hard at all to pass the class with a good grade. you don't have to devote a lot of time to it at all. you'll be fine. you just won't be engaged in the material and around holidays/the end of class, if you are still attending it in person? you'll be part of the minority. a couple of times there was truly just a handful of us.

i think the only thing specific to this class was middle english and manuscripts coming up in non-english major class that I was able to give more context on, and then being able to go into the Beinecke and touch some really manuscripts, prayer books, and scrolls. 

i'd maybe read the poems/songlines that were assigned for the day once through an hour before the class and that would be more than enough to get through the class and be thanked for participation. i did maybe one or two of the additional readings and that was enough to draw on for the essays.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course because of the amount of freedom offered on the midterm and final assignments. The course felt like it was set up to encourage an approach from many different perspectives, and I think this is really appealing.
Yes, it was fun and quite interesting with a great professor

I would absolutely recommend this course. It's one of my favorites that I've taken at Yale. Professor Butterfield is amazing, and I really valued the opportunity to study from manuscripts (or digital images of manuscripts) every week.
Yes, certainly for anyone interested in the Medieval period.

hello english majors and weird strains of theater and/or music majors. if you're an English major and this is one of the 1-2 medieval courses offered this semester, go ahead and take it. you'll be very bored and complain to your other english major friends about how you have no idea what this course is supposed to accomplish, but you'll pass it and be fine. 

to the theater and/or music people, idk if this is your jam or whatever, go ahead and enjoy your niche? I'm sure you have other options that will be more engaging. if not, the previous english major message applies.

No. This course strongly focuses on lyricization of poetic Middle English texts, which is to my understanding, taking them at face value and removing them from their original contexts, but the class would have benefitted from more lecture-style sessions in which we learn how to conceive of religion, culture, and language in England at the time these texts were written. I came into this course with interests in linguistics and music and this course was not well-developed in either of these areas. I was disappointed that there was not any instruction on pronunciation of Middle English, and as a result when we read poetry out loud it involved a lot of guesswork. Prof. Butterfield provided modern glosses for difficult Middle English words, but we never learned about Middle Englishs grammatical differences that are so important in parsing the unfamiliar poetry that we read. The musical aspect of this course was extremely minimal - twice we attempted to read from (rather difficult) sheet music which was fun for some of the class but impossible for others. If you do not understand basic Christian imagery you will also struggle.
